content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

This thumbnail displays multiple fragments of fibro-adipose tissue. There are several densely cellular, basophilic (purple) nodules embedded within the fat, which are highly characteristic of lymph nodes. I can identify at least one or two distinct potential lymph nodes, with the most prominent one located in the upper portion of the image.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist staging a colorectal cancer case, the primary objective is to identify all lymph nodes and meticulously examine them for metastatic disease. The area indicated by the green box is the most conspicuous and well-defined lymph node candidate on the slide. It is standard practice to begin the systematic review by examining the most obvious lymph nodes first. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view confirms the presence of a lymph node, partially surrounded by adipose tissue. The node is composed of dense lymphoid tissue with recognizable follicular structures. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, abnormal glandular formations, or nests of tumor cells that would indicate metastasis from a colorectal adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific lymph node is that it is benign and reactive, and therefore negative for metastasis.
